title: HTML Forms & Input
description: Create interactive forms with input fields
instructions: Build a form with text input, email, and submit button. Use proper HTML5 input types.
hints: Use <form> element to wrap your form controls
Add type='email' to validate email inputs
Add type='text' for regular text inputs
Use addEventListener to handle form submissions
Call preventDefault() to stop default form submission

starterCode.html: <!-- Create a form element here -->
starterCode.javascript: // Add form handling code here!

title: HTML Lists & Tables
description: Organize data with lists and tables
instructions: Create an ordered list and a simple table with headers and data rows.
hints: Use <ol> for ordered lists and <ul> for unordered lists
Use <li> to define list items
Tables use <table>, <thead>, <tbody>, <tr>, <th>, and <td>
<thead> groups header rows, <tbody> groups data rows
<th> is for header cells, <td> is for data cells

title: JavaScript Variables & Data Types
description: Learn about let, const, and data types
instructions: Explore strings, numbers, booleans, arrays, and objects in JavaScript.
hints: Use const by default, let when reassignment is needed
Strings are wrapped in quotes: 'hello' or "hello"
Arrays are created with square brackets: [1, 2, 3]
Objects use curly braces: { name: 'John', age: 30 }
Use typeof to check variable types

starterCode.html: <!-- Declare variables and explore data types here -->
starterCode.javascript:
// Create const and let variables with different data types
// Log them to console to explore types

title: JavaScript Functions
description: Create reusable code with functions
instructions: Write functions with parameters and return values. Try arrow functions too!
hints: Functions are defined with function keyword: function name() {}
Arrow functions use =>: const name = () => {}
Parameters go in parentheses: function add(a, b) {}
Use return to send values back from functions
Functions can be called multiple times
